channel.title: Portable Wisdom
channel.description: Lists, Models and Quotes of Broad Interest and Application

item.title: When racial or religious lines are drawn by the State
item.description: When racial or religious lines are drawn by the State, the multi-racial, multi-religious communities that our Constitution seeks to weld together as one become separatist; antagonisms that relate to race or to religion, rather than to political issues, are generated; communities seek not the best representative, but the best racial or religious partisan.

item.title: The Scientific Method
item.description: The scientific method is an empirical method of acquiring knowledge that has characterized the development of science.

item.title: 7 Habits of Highly Effective People
item.description: The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People® is, of course, the famous list from Stephen R. Covey's book of the same name.

item.title: Elements of an Improvement Process
item.description:
All living things are interested in improvement, whether it’s improving ourselves, our society, our processes, our products, or our species.

But how does improvement work?

Below I’ve listed the elements of an improvement process.

item.title: The Four-Fold Way
item.description:
The Four-Fold Way® come from the book of the same name, by Angeles Arrien.

1. The Way of the Warrior

Show up, and choose to be present.

item.description:
In his research Dr. John Gottman identified the following relationship-destroying communication patterns.

To reverse or correct these patterns, he also developed Antidotes to The Four Relationship Horsemen.

item.title: 7 Ways to Think Like a 21st Century Economist
item.description:
These come from Kate Raworth’s book Doughnut Economics.

1. Change the Goal

from GDP to the Doughnut

Traditional economics sets the goal of continually increasing Gross Domestic Product.

item.title: The Cynefin Framework
item.description: Dave Snowden’s Cynefin framework offers a useful guide to differing approaches that are appropriate for situations with varying degrees of certainty.

item.title: Steps in Decision-Making Conversations
item.description: These come from Craig Weber, and are described in his book Conversational Capacity (although I originally picked them up as part of a consulting engagement with Craig).

item.title: The Dreyfus Model of Skill Acquisition
item.description:
First proposed by Stuart and Hubert Dreyfus in 1980, this model suggests that people go through roughly five stages as they acquire new skills.

I first heard of this model from Dan North, who first made me aware of the Dreyfus model and some of its implications in the…

item.title: The DRAMMA List of Psychological Needs
item.description: DRAMMA is a theory outlining six pschological needs that, when satisfied, lead to optimal functioning and higher levels of well-being. DRAMMA is notable for integrating leisure needs with other psychological needs more typically associated with work.

item.title: DRIVE: Motivational Factors for Complex Work
item.description:
In is book Drive, Daniel H. Pink identified three vital sources of extrinsic motivation for individuals engaged in something more complex than simple, straightforward tasks.

Many people have heard of these three factors via this lively video created by RSA Animate.

item.title: Self-Determination Theory
item.description:
Self-Determination Theory identifies three basic psychological needs that must be satisfied to foster well-being and health.

1. Autonomy

People need to feel essential control of their own behaviors and goals; however this does not mean being independent of others.

item.title: Developmental Levels
item.description: A number of authors and systems of thought espouse one or another series of developmental levels, in fields of study as diverse as psychology, sociology, economics and organizational development.

item.title: The Urgent vs. Important Matrix
item.description:
This is a tool to help manage the allocation of resources to tasks.

You will also sometimes see this referred to as the Eisenhower Matrix, and will sometimes see it credited to Stephen Covey, who helped to popularize it.

item.title: The Four Quadrants
item.description:
I originally came across this model in a book by Ken Wilber, titled A Brief History of Everything.

It’s become a foundational piece of Wilber’s Integral Philosophy, something he terms AQAL, for All Quadrants, All Levels.

item.title: The Rotarian Four-Way Test
item.description:
The Four-Way Test is a nonpartisan and nonsectarian ethical guide for Rotarians to use for their personal and professional relationships.

The test is widely promoted as one of the guiding principles of Rotary International.

item.title: Four Sentences that Lead to Wisdom
item.description:
These sentences come from author Louise Penny, and are passed on by her detective protagonist, Armand Gamache, in several of her books.

  1. I am sorry.
  2. I was wrong.
  3. I don’t know.
  4. I need help.

item.title: The Four Essential Attributes of Any Organization
item.description:
In order to survive and thrive, any organization must possess the following four characteristics.

  • Identity - The organization must know who they are.
  • Integrity - The organization must act in accordance with its identity.
